Nope.
The graphics were impressive in their day, and they're still pretty artistic, but they're not great shakes by modern standards. The writing might have been ok before it was translated from the French. The voice-acting is... I'll be generous and say "mixed". The fascinating puzzle mechanisms promised by the game's aesthetics just don't feature. The puzzles come in three flavours:
1) Incredibly simple but tedious, usually involving a lot of walking back and forwards and waiting for slow scene transitions that can't be sped up
2) obtuse and silly - "I know there's a hotspot here and I have a thing I can use on it, I've no idea what it'll do but I might as well try it"
3) hidden object puzzles but worse - "find the tiny hotspot that looks exactly the same as the rest of the stupid cave".
Frequently, you can't proceed without first speaking to a particular NPC about a particular thing, and the dialog in question won't be available until you've done something else elsewhere... in practice, this means you just spend a lot of time walking back and forth talking to every NPC about every little thing, hearing the same information from a dozen different sources, getting tips for puzzles you've long ago solved, just in the hope that prompting the right idiot about the right thing will magically open the way forward.
If you want a drop-dead-gorgeous game with cool mechanical puzzles, play Quern. If you want a really good point-and-click adventure with a great story and good voice-acting, play Memoria. If you want a hidden object game, play one of those. Don't play this tripe.

I would recommend Syberia to any fan of the point and click genre without hesitation.
The core puzzles within the game are excellent. They make sense, that's the important part for any good point and click adventure game. There's no 'click on this pixel for no apparent reason' or anything like that. There are a couple of quite challenging one's but nothing that just a minute of logical thinking can't overcome.
The only part of the game that left me feeling a little disappointed was the story. It set's itself up really well and leave's question's waiting to be answered. The problem is, for most of the game you're involved in challenge's which have absolutely nothing to do with the story.
This in turn make's the story a rather routine quest to find someone and not much more.
This of course is only looking at the game as a stand alone experience. Syberia 2 and 3 will do so much more to expand on the story told here. It's only really something that will bother those not wanting to play the trilogy.
I see people complaining that the game hasn't aged well. I really don't think it's that bad. I followed the small Windows 10 instructions within the Steam forums to get it working. After that, it only crashed once and I had no other real issues playing. The graphic's still do the job just fine.
If you're a point and click fan, go ahead a buy it. If you're interested in the story, only buy it if you plan on playing Syberia 2 and 3 as well.

I went into this game thinking that I would like it. With some of my absolute favorite games being adventure games, and with this one appearing to be both very unique and interesting, I can sadly not say that Syberia is one of them.
While it suffers from the same problems that a lot of older adventure games does - clunky interface and controls, unintuitive solutions to puzzles, and so on - that's far from the full extent of Syberias problems.
Now, adventure games are supposed to have a slower pace than many other game genres, but Syberia
slows it down.
To the point where it places visual aestethics before accessibility or gameplay. There are many places where you are forced to traverse unnecessarily long distances between points you need to interact with, and there are entire screens whose sole purpose seem to just be nice to look at.
It's like being trapped in a series of beautiful paintings.
And while they are (for the most part)  absolutely gorgeous, I can't help thinking how the effort that went into making them that way would have been much better spent on making fewer screens which were used more efficiently.
Syberia is an experience which have stayed with me for a long time, but probably for the wrong reasons.

To this day, it's still a really good point-and-click, with a lot of charm and a very distinctive style. The puzzles aren't too hard or weird (if you think they are, you clearly haven't played a lot of adventure games), even though I struggled to find some objects/elements more than necessary. The art is absolutely gorgeous, if you can look past the outdated 3D. It just didn't age very well at all, in term of game mechanics and controls. Some coding glitches, a few puzzles that are just annoying to go through by today standards, dialogues sounding illogical at times. Inability to skip from one screen to the other and having to watch Kate walk everywhere was also a pain.
But when you play an old game, you kind of expect these kind of inconviences, and the game has more than enough qualities to make up for it. A nice set of old-fahsioned adventure game characters (Oscar is amazing), a poetic story, with some quite dark moments if you ask me, I was still immersed and interested enough to want to play it all the way through.
So, if you like old school point-and-clicks, you'll most likely love this. If you don't, chances are you won't enjoy it.

Graphics are decent for the time, and if you like click adventure games, you'll have no problem being immersed.
But the story is very light. There is no strong sense of mystery, the puzzles are too easy, and there are easily missable plot points. Early on, the character jumps on a train that will take her on a very long journey. How long the journey is, whereto, or why you should ho on it, is not clear to either the character or the player unless you read a particular letter. Neither the actions nor thoughts of the character is clear at any one point, which is why I can't be bothered finising this title.
Syberia is one of the best adventure games ever made. Its amazing visuals and great story make it a must-play for every adventure games fan.

Let me start out by saying I've played some adventure point-and-click games before, and while it is not my favourite genre, I can usually sit through until the end of the game. Not so here - I did not finish even half of this title.
To be perfectly honest, I would rather give this game neutral feedback. I enjoy the artwork and movies - so much clockwork architecture and clever designs given life. What I experienced of the story is interesting, and has a level of realism to it other games in the genre lack. The phone calls especially add to this.
Unfortunately the story is so slow and drawn out that, even though it is interesting stuff, it ends up just being a snooze-fest. Find an object to interact with or another zone to enter, click, wait. Rinse and repeat. All you end up doing is watch a pixellated person walking around all day, while you twiddle your thumbs waiting for Kate to finish your last instruction.
There's a reason why I say it's a staircase simulator. Most developers of this type of game would understand the need to put area divisions instead of things like stairs and ladders, which everyone knows are utterly boring and unnecessary. This game doesn't. Instead, all that boring stuff is included in the gameplay. Meaning there isn't any gameplay, just climbing. This is a pretty major let down, one that you can't ignore when deciding on whether to play or not.
It is good for one thing though - falling asleep at the keyboard. If you've never done that before and you're having trouble, just play this and you'll nod off without a hitch ;)
There are a lot of annoying things that artificially draw out the game and make it long-winded. Things like turning around to climb down stairs backwards, even though it looks fine to just climb down normally. The train driver automaton being a b*tch about paperwork and travel visas. Way, way, way too many pointless stairs that could have just been eliminated from the artwork in the first place to give the game better pacing.
So the game is both enjoyable and a snooze-fest. It can have great atmosphere, despite the slog, with great ambience in some areas, with things like birds and sounds helping to bring it to life, but this just wasn't enough for me. I'll just join Kate and go to sleep in the train.

I praised the first game for avoiding non-sensical puzzles, but this game dives straight into those waters. I doubt I would have completed the game without the aid of online assistance.
While I have to recommend the game for those wishing to complete the story, I definitely feel that the first Syberia is the far superior adventure gaming experience.

Oh well ... it's an ok game.
If you're a fan of logic puzzles, you may like it better. But me, having played it for the story, I felt all the puzzles (with partly not entirely credible solutions,) all the tedious and time-consuming running back and forth to find stuff and apply it to other stuff in the right order (and even if you guess a solution you can't try it out before finding the right clue, or even when you fish the umpteenth blue salmon that you know the brown bear doesn't like, you can't just ditch it but have to run through several rooms to feed it to the bear just so your basket is empty to take new fish) and all those obstacles springing up from out of nowhere all the time distracting me from advancing the story.
With part 1 I checked a walkthrough occasionally. With part 2 I started real early, because not only does part 2 only show things you can interact with on mouse-over, but it also introduces panning screens. So you actually have to run to every corner of every screen to see if it starts panning and maybe reveals another exit. Or things that look like one big thing to interact with are sometimes multiple items and you end up clicking all over every interaction piece to make sure you don't miss anything. The last quarter of the game I basically finished with a walkthrough in front of me, because I was just fed up with all the distractions.
If you're looking for crazy puzzles and machines with lots of levers and buttons to be pressed in the right order, you'll be fine. If you enjoy such puzzles, you may even like the game, a lot, and get to appreciate the charming story that _is_ in there, somewhere. If you want the charming story and couldn't care less about all the complicated machines popping up in the most unlikely places, you may (like me) have difficulties. Imagine a book where every chapter starts with "And then they wanted to continue their journey, but couldn't."

Great adventure game with a beautiful story!  It's about a American lawyer, Kate Walker, who is sent to France to complete the buyout of an automaton toy factory.  In the beginning, Kate's mindset is to get the heir of the toy factory to sign the contract and then fly back home immediately.  Seems like a easy task at first, but Kate soon finds out that the task is a lot more complicated than anticipated.  To find what she is looking for, she must travel across different locations.
The story starts off a bit slow, but things become more interesting the further you get into it. During her journey, you can sense that Kate's character evolves throughout.  The things that she was concerned about at the beginning of the journey become less important to her later on.  It is a journey not only about traveling to different locations, but also a journey about finding herself.  I was intrigued through most of it, and I thought the ending was very fitting!
And yes, there are puzzles.  Some of the puzzles can be challenging, but I did not find any of them to be extremely difficult... Getting through the game without a walkthrough is feasible.  Soundtrack is very soothing, and the scenery is gorgeous.  For being a 2002 game, the graphics are really top-notch!  The game can also be funny at times!
I went through this game for the first time just recently (and I never played any other games developed by Microids), so I'm not speaking out of nostalgia.  But after playing this, I'd like to try out some of their other games... as well as games that Benoît Sokal worked on.
For anyone else that enjoys adventure games, I highly recommend this!

Note: This review pertains to the Macintosh version of Syberia.
Syberia is a classic point-and-click adventure game with an immersive story, great production values, and streamlined gameplay. The presentation is a little creaky after 16 years, but this is a game that should be played by anyone who appreciates a good story.
Most impressive is the sense of immersion in intricate environments stretching from the French Alps, across Eastern Europe and the former USSR, to the shores of the erstwhile Aral Sea. While the character models render at native resolution, the pre-rendered background appear grainy and pixelated at contemporary monitor resolutions. Fortunately, the production design is uniformly excellent and each location feels like a real, lived-in place.
Many adventure games of the 1990s relied upon arcane puzzles and tedious pixel hunts to pad out their length. Syberia forgoes any of this nonsense and displays icons over every piece of environment that is interactive. While this breaks the immersion somewhat, it also streamlines the gameplay. Puzzles are logically presented and won't have players running for a walkthrough.
The game ends somewhat abruptly and essentially requires purchase of the sequel to continue the story. Despite a few niggling issues, this is a game that everyone should play.

PROs:
- very cool story
- awesome graphics, done by a Belgian comic artist, and it shows
- it has that certain je ne sais quoi that will keep you hooked even if you are not a fan of the genre
- since it is not too long or too complicated, once you are hooked, you will see the story through and enjoy it
- unique, memorable characters.  The robot's voice will stay with me for a long while
CONs:
- I thought it wouldn't be the case, but there absolutely are situations where if you fail to hover the cursor over a particular area, you will never advance; this is exacerbated by the fact that the graphics are so nice and uniform - it's not like in the older adventure games where the usable objects were drawn differently from the background
- the puzzles themselves are somewhat of an engima - some are not even puzzles at all, and just require clicking to activate, whereas others rely on an obsessive attention to details

Syberia is a tour-de-force in the point-and-click genre of the gaming world, maybe not just even within its own genre. The story is both intriguing and compelling, the graphics still look great and hold their details, and the characters are awesome, interesting, funny, and tragic.
This game shows off the artistic talent and genius of Benoit Sokal, a Beligian comic artist and the game developer for Syberia I and II. After my last time playing it, I began to realize the small details that make a game's story great and its characters equally so. Our main protagonist, named Kate Walker, is an international lawyer from a law firm in New York...and her life there is less than satisfactory. Granted, these details are revealed through short phone calls with her doting, somewhat air-headed mother, her so-called "best friend" Olivia, her impatient, jaded boss, and her fiance, whom Kate discovers over the period of the game she is not compatible with. Good thing too, because her fiance is a total ***hole.
The stark contrast between her life in New York City as a lawyer (which, like I said, is only revealed through a series of phone calls over a period of the gameplay) and her travels throughout Europe looking for an old man with a fierce imagination and an obvious genius as she visits the *often* sad, small towns with their eccentric residents show us that our main protagonist is evolving a newer, more enlightened perspective. She starts out cynical and jaded, yet as she continues on her journey to search for Hans Voralberg, a brilliant inventor with a child-like mind and personae, she becomes more aware or her surroundings and the people she encounters, and begins to realize that there is more to life than crony, greedy bosses andcheating partners. She found a whole new world of wanderlust and the mechanical dreams of a brilliant progeny, and you bet she's going pursue it. Syberia absolutely shows our heroine evolving as the train she's boarded on plunges deeper into the arctic tundras of freezing, desolate Russia.
This game has a steampunk aesthetic, and has an acute sense of small, mechanical detail. Of course, this is one of the highlight;s of Syberia. Steampunk is a very difficult genre to work with, as it relies on both fantastical yet realistic, mechanical elements. Of course, Benoit Sokal knew what he was doing and not only used steampunk in an aesthetic sense, but manager to interweave its elements to♥♥♥♥♥highlights to the importance of the story.

Unfortunately, especially for me, the sequel to Syberia really isn't as good as the original.
The big thing is that it lacks the atmosphere of the original, which is probably the biggest factor in the original being so good. Why did it lack it? There's a bunch of reasons. The soundtrack isn't as catching, imagery isn't as distinctive (due to all the snow), seemingly more stilted dialogue/VA, and etc. The game also includes a subplot which, frankly, is more distracting than complimenting.
Another big reason is that there aren't as many locations. The original Syberia has four distinct locations -- Syberia 2 has two. Both games have areas 'in-between', but, even then, the 'in-between' areas of the original carried a far stronger impression because there is more unique imagery. The 'in-between' areas of Syberia 2 is mostly bland snow.
So all of the above combined to dramatically decreased the atmosphere of Syberia 2 to its detriment. However, I still recommend it for fans of the original because the game is a major plot continuation of the story from the first game. I suppose if you don't care for the original's story, that won't matter, but I grew to love Kate/Oscar/Hans so I really wanted to know what happens next.
On its own, I honestly wouldn't recommend it, but if you love the original and/or, like me, preparing for the upcoming release of Syberia 3, this game would be a worthy purchase.

This is more of an intellectual and philosophic experience than a game. That said, it is highly recommendable. You will feel cultured while being more engaged than watching a movie.
Pros:
Lovely scenery and voice work. The music, too, fits the ambience. I particularly enjoyed the theme in the communist factory.
The story. As I said, this isn’t so much a game as a guided experience. Syberia has been described as “a journey through the failed utopias of the 20th century” which is a wonderful explanation. I would add that it is an exploration of the topics of obsession, disappointment, age, and lost potential. A deeply melancholic and thoughtful experience with a well written story and characters.
Cons:
The puzzles weren’t particularly challenging. Some had a bit of a forced logic to solve them or went a bit against intuition, which can be frustrating. However, the game doesn’t resort to the too common “push the boxes” or “arrange the pipes/wires/yarn” kind of puzzles so at least every problem is an original one.
On occasion I felt that the pace was a bit slow and that I had to do a lot of reading. However, take this with a grain of salt. Since the steam version comes with six languages I used the game to improve my French (very good voice work, by the way) so I may not be totally fair here. You will have to read, though, and pay attention to details.
Playing Syberia is like being inside one of those independent films that get the Golden Lion in Venice’s film festival. Sweet, gentle and meditative.

I am a total sucker for adventure games. My love affair with them started way back with Colassal cave, Scott Adams Adventures, and the famous Infocom games. Back then things were text based. Wishbringer, Hitchhiker's Guide to the galaxy, Enchanter, Suspended, Planetfall, Bureaucracy, The Lurking HOrror, and the everpopular ZORK were among my favorites. Adventure games have one game play premise. The Barter System (and right now the This for That Schoolhouse Rock song is playing in my head).  But that is the essence of the system. I have this, I give this person THAT and get another thing in return or they do something for me. Thus I progress in the story.
Now the purpose really is to tell a fun and interesting story while loading up with these puzzle exchanges. Graphics adventures of the sort were inevitable. THe best known were the Sierra company's titles like the King's QUest series, thus the POINT AND CLICK adventure was born. Thus a problem. Instead of getting a description of a room and things you can pick up, you are given a picture and have to see that these blocky pictures are actually objects as well as that there are exits...and sometimes not. Sure you can hover over an area to see if you can interact, but therein lies the problem. You HAVE to make things logical enough so that people will not only be able to tell where to go and that there might be something you can pick up.
Syberia 2 suffers bigtime from both obstacles. It is a sequel to a previous Syberia game, but that doesn't really matter. YOu can pick up easily that the lead character Kate has been away from work for awhile...and never wants to return. She instead sets off on another journey with an elderly friend to find Syberia, a place of myth and legend. It's an intriguing beginning that basically leads nowhere fast. Like King's Quest V, it suffers from lots of illogic in tasks you must do. Give a alligator to this character to get a key? No that's an exaggeration but there are some of the puzzles like that. THere is a lot of bait and switch in it. Oh I need a small key to get through this door. Rats. It doesn't work I think. Am I doing this right? I need a coin for this contraption. I have many coins. They don't seem to work. I have no idea what to do now.
This uncertainty is there because of the gameplay engine. When you hover it is a bit ambivvalent in what's happening. It uses a weird symbol to indicate that you CAN'T do something that is small and unclear and most importantly unlabeled and uninstructed. There is NO instruction whatsoever in fact. So you will waste a lot of time, say....trying a key in a door and wondering what you are doing wrong, not totally realizing that....it's just the wrong key....go find another one. It doesn't tell you it is wrong in ways that are obvious. Other games have big eyeball icons for looking, speech ballon for talking, hand for grabbing. Can't really say I can identify what the cursor is doing at any particular time except that it changes. Another gameplay issue is objects. You can use objects in your inventory to interact with objects in a given location. That isn't really obvious either. Mixed with the obtuse icons and cursors it takes a bit to figure it out when a simple 1 minute training area would have taken care of this.
It also definitely lacks logic in that it won't let you say and do things that seem obvious. Example. You talk to someone. They have a broken thing. You have a long conversation about your goal, your traveling companion, his ability to invent and fix things and that the two character even KNOW each other. THen in the end nothing becomes of it. It is obvious that you should go back to your friend and talk to him to tell him to go fix the thing right? But when you do it doesn't give you that option. Why not? I think the characters stand around asking themselves that.
The characters are indeed very good characters, some a bit natural, some cartoony. The lead character especially is appealing. However most of the characters don't want to help you with anything. Then out of nowhere they do. Then instead of actually saying logical things that flow, they clam up simply waiting around...bored in their existance. They almost look like they are frustrated about having nothing interesting to say. Talking with someone is easy. Just click on them and it gives you a series of topics to discuss. But that soon becomes a complete grind. They recycle information SO MUCH within each topic. Nothing goes in sequential order. You can get 5 layers deep in ONE topic conversation only to be told the exact same thing 2 layers down in another. And those conversations seem to go on forever without really getting to the point.
I do like the characters in general. The stories of each person are fine and make you want to know them more. The lead character is appealing enough to easily get most people on her side. But....this game and story is a bit of a depressing downer right from the getgo. I love the beginning of how her bosses are worried about her and that she hasn't come back to the office. "She's gone." says one. Meaning...wanderlust has totally consumed her. She's a different person now and will never return. Kate does indeed to be fulfilling that role...trying to help her dying old inventor friend find the mythical Syberia. So good strong beginning instantly sent on a downward depressing spiral dealing with an elderly friend whose mind is not all there and whose health slowly
fact there are a series of interactions and puzzles dealing specifically with that. I don't want to watch a man dying and have to go through a lot of things just to get him treated just to be told he's going to die. On the upside this is a world like MYST, like Likehouse. Full of robots and contrption. Granted it has this supercharged locatamotive run by a robot and still has to use coal. What's with that? It then goes through a town whose economy is nonexistent because it has no travelers or money coming in on the last stop to nowhere. No wonder all the characters just stand around fidgety waiting for something to happen (which never does)
Overall there is no brightness at all to this game. Not in puzzles, not in interaction, not in story, not in logic. THere are some things that you just happen upon and they work. THere are others you didn't even realize and never would have guessed. THen there is the problem of having to constantly go from one of a towen to the other to your train back again, etc. It's a grind. Not fun at all. Especially when location logic too seems to suffer. LEt's see if I go under the train track I should be here then back this way I'm at the stairs. No wait I'm now at an engine. BUt that should be over by the house. Location placement is a bit off and not logical either making that running grind worse. Putting things as far apart as possible just to lengthen gameplay and then confuse you in how to get there....is a very very bad idea.
At end, the only great thing to say about this is that the characters are well formed, the scenerey gorgeous, the voice acting is great, especially Kate and the pearshaped Russian guy that sounds like Boris Badenov from Bullwinkle.

I've been thinking of how to rate Syberia as there is a great amount of the Good as there is of the Bad. But which part outweighs which is the real question. Well, let's break it down.
You play as an American lawyer Kate Walker who's on a trip to a fictional village in France to sign a contract for a toy factory takeover. Unfortunately, its current owner passes away and there's only one person left in the family to give her the signature. However, their whereabouts are unknown and so Kate's journey across Central and Easter Europe starts.
Going further into the plot would reveal major spoilers so I'll leave it at that. The locations in the game are built around the steampunk aesthetic and come with a huge attention to detail. Highly immersive ambience and a beautiful soundtrack. As you traverse the areas, you stumble upon several characters, documents and of course occasional puzzles that progress the story. Nothing groundbreaking about the dialogue and not only do you have to read A LOT, you also have to memorize certain bits as they hold clues to some of the puzzles. For someone who loves to read, this isn't a minus but it does extend the playtime artificially. The game ends abruptly with a cliffhanger and leaves just enough room for a sequel.
Now, since this is an interactive adventure and not just a movie, I have to address it's problems in that department. First of all, the pacing. It really puts your patience to the test, running between interest points takes forever...and you will hate the stairs here. Absolutely everything takes too long to execute. There is another game made by the same developer, Still Life, which shares some similarities with Syberia, except that it never felt like a drag. This is a huge deal and I don't need to explain how awful it becomes when you get lost or just can't find the next clue. Speaking of, the puzzles range from simplistic "use the items you found along your path" to frustrating "how in hell would you figure that out". As stated earlier, the solution is sometimes to be attained from the found documents, but you never really know when you make use of it. Which again leads to thinking whether you could have missed something when in fact it's right there in your inventory. Another issue I didn't have to deal with in Still Life.
All things considered, if you are up to experience a memorable narrative taking its painfully dull and slow progress into account, this might be a good pick for you.

Couple Warnings:
1) This review covers both Syberia games.
2) While I'm saying I don't recommend it, I'm not saying it's a bad game. Hear me out, here.
Not too long ago they had the "Syberia Bundle" on sale, so I thought I'd buy it with nothing to lose. It couldn't be that bad, if there's another sequel on the way, right?
Again, as an adventure game, it's not bad. In fact, I think it did pretty good at setting up some challenging puzzles. But it's also nothing special. In a game like this, solving a puzzle is supposed to mean advancing the plot, but this game has barely enough plot to write a single novella, even if you use 100% of content from both Syberia games.
Here's a quick TL;DR:
1) The plot is weak and nonsensical.
2) World building and character development were thrown out the window altogether. You just have to take everyone's word for it that "Kate's Changed," because I can't tell a difference.
3) The game features some glaring samples of bad level design, forcing the player to deal with issues that game devs had known were bad ideas for at least a decade before.
((((SPOILER))))
Plot of the first game can be summed up as "Young Lawyer Kate Walker goes to France to finalize paperwork on an automaton factory's takeover after the owner dies. However, the owner reveals in her will that her brother was still alive, and therefore she wants all her assets sent to him. All things considered, this should have still been the end of Kate's job, but her boss tells her not to come home until she gets that paperwork signed, so she travels to Russia hoping that just sort of maybe this brother will be there. On her way, we learn that her boss is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and that her boyfriend is cheating on her with her best friend. All things considered, it's somewhat understandable that she chooses to run away with this brother, Hans, once she finally meets him." Sure, there's a train whose engineer is a robot who is your companion, but he refuses to lift a finger to assist in any way beyond "drive the train."
Second game, Kate's traveling with Oscar the robot train driver and Hans the mammoth-obsessed idiot whose only redeeming feature is his ability to make Automatons. Hans gets sick and nearly dies, but he gets better after killing Oscar and turning his body into a brace. In the end, you make it to the magical island of Syberia, where wooly mammoths are still alive. ((((END SPOILER))))
Considering what I know about the story so far, Syberia III is most likely going to just be "Kate goes back to civilization after completing her journey" and that's all we're going to get. And the worst part is, Kate's motivation is never clear. If these games made anything clear about her, it's that she isn't an idiot by any stretch of the imagination. Plus she was a lawyer. She knew her rights. She knew that her boss couldn't exactly fire her just because he didn't know all the facts before sending her into the field and it turns out the situation was more complicated than they expected. If she loved her job so much that she was willing to travel from France to Russia just to get one document signed, she would have known that travelling from France to Russia alone with no help was beyond her job description. Why the hell did she decide to throw away her relationships just to make her ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss happy?
My other major complaint about the game is that there is next to no world building or character development, although I guess I already talked about poor character development. One of the main staples of point and click adventure games is that you can click on things to learn about them, or at least what the character knows about it. This helps you understand your environment and your character, but it's something that was sorely lacking from this game. Even some of those stupid Putt Putt and Freddie Fish games from the late 90's/early 2000's for kids 6 and under (which I played when I was 6 and under) did a better job of this, and they did it for an audience with a much shorter attention span. This game was for the 16-20 audience, and failed to deliver on one of the simplest questions anyone could ask of a story: "Why should I care?" Due to the fact you're surrounded by  strange devices, the sci-fi loving part of me cared from the first cutscene, but I could never rationalize caring beyond that.
Lastly, although I've said many times that the game aspect was good, this game is the poster child for bad level design. In Syberia I, you are forced to run from one area to another multiple times, and half the areas in between bear no relevance to solving any puzzles or continuing the story. In Syberia II, they don't fix it. In fact, the only thing that got an update as far as I could tell was the layout of the train interior. That made no sense to update, though, since there would have been no time or reason for our characters to renovate it. I mean, Syberia II picks up one stop after Syberia I as far as I can tell. But that's the biggest gripe I think you can throw at any game series: This was a problem in the first game. You didn't fix it.
Last thing. You know how the bullet points here on Steam say that the game has "Rich and intriguing new characters with new, realistically detailed 3D environments?" ignoring the game's age, I can't tell a difference between the graphics from the first game and the  second game. Also, the new characters? One's a dog, the other's a thief who follows you. I will say, though, that the dog is a good boy.
I regret to say that once Syberia III costs 12.99 or less, I'll probably cave and buy it as well, but I can't see it being anything other than a quick cash grab.

Hans is determined to go to the island and witness the site of the mammoths that he'd dreamed of since childhood. Kate, who previously spent a lot of time hunting down and learning more about Hans, is also determined to help the kind elderly automaton builder fullfill his dream. During their travels, they encounter both kind folk and intimedating foes, as well as dangers of the wilderness that effects the journey in some ways. The point-and-click adventure genre isn't one that I hear about much these days. Their heyday was primarily in the late 80s and mid-90s. But in those times the interfaces were clunkier and the games themselves were often 2D or some hybrid of FMV and pseudo-3D. Along comes Syberia in 2002 to deliver us an adventure realized in fully 3D character models, attractive pre rendered backgrounds, and an intriguing premise. It's well appreciated.
Syberia follows Kate Walker, a New York lawyer sent into the French Alps to settle the acquisition of a clockwork toy factory by a massive American corporation. As expected, such routine matters do not go as expected and Kate learns that the owner of the factory has passed away and left information about a long-lost brother who is now heir to the factory. Kate leaves on a journey that takes her across western and eastern Europe, retracing the heir's steps, hounded by phone calls from her increasingly livid boss and faithless fiance.
The interface for Syberia is quite clean. Inventory, notes, and clues are gathered into a single menu that unfolds into a second section depending on what you want to use or examine. I never got lost searching for information or items. Likewise, the conversation system is also simple and easy to manage. Kate has access to a limited number of topics (she can learn more) that can be used on most NPCs. As opposed to some of the adventure games of yesteryear that allowed the player to type in potential keywords and/or questions during conversations, Syberia keeps things mostly linear and self-contained.
The atmosphere of Syberia reminds me of a Victorian era novel. The artwork is often ornate and based in art nouveau with its love for arcs and curves. The clockwork toy factory and its automaton creations evoke steampunk imagery that blends the setting between the real and surreal. Lighting and weather effects deliver a sense that Kate is drifting further and further into an unknown frontier. Civilization grows more sparse and eccentric as she journeys, but not at the cost of tone. Syberia is occasionally satirical and tongue-in-cheek with its dialogue, but rarely becomes so silly that the overall mystery and emerging wonder of the world is lost.
At its heart,  Syberia is a story about self-discovery as much as answering the mystery of the lost heir. Kate's interactions with other characters evolve subtly. Much like her boss and fiance, Kate begins her story focused on business and the superficiality of modern American life. As she delves deeper into the story of the clockwork factory, its late owner, and missing heir, she awakens to feelings and ideas she never expected. Her mission is soon driven as much by curiosity and fascination as obligation to her work. Phone calls with friends, family, and work grow less familiar as Kate's emotional and psychological distance from them gradually matches her geographical distance.
The puzzles are pretty simple and most can be solved with items and clues found nearby. I did have some issues with the conversation system that wasted time, though. Sometimes in the process of solving a puzzle, you must return to an NPC you already spoke to and try exhausting the dialogue options with them again because they have something new to say or give you. The linearity of some solutions harms the game occasionally. I would go through dialogue topics out of order from what the developers seemed to expect more often than not, receiving information and puzzle prompts that weren't properly solvable yet. I would run around confused for several minutes before finally returning and discover that I had to ask about something else that would cause the NPC to give me the item I needed to solve the puzzle they already sent me after. Fortunately, this only happened a few times.
The pacing of the story becomes a bit rushed during its third act. There's a villain character who I would've enjoyed learning more about, but the developers were content to keep their villain mostly one-dimensional. The conflict the villain introduces builds up, climaxes, and then gets resolved so quickly that I wonder now if there had been a longer story arc for this encounter that was abandoned during development. However, the overall narrative of Syberia remains intact and only becomes more interesting, hiccups aside. It whacks you with a big cliffhanger, but I was enthusiastic about it, not annoyed. I'm of the mind that if a game ends leaving you genuinely interested in playing its sequel or even just playing the game again, it's automatically a recommendation.

This adventure game has easy puzzles, and it doesn't get into the steampunk mechanics the way you might be hoping for--like most things, it uses them for atmosphere. But, oh man, does this game have atmosphere.
Playing Syberia is a little bit like reading a book from the 1800s. Slow-paced, a little dated, and a little cliche. But if you, like me, enjoy quieting your mind a little to take in all the beauty of something like that, you're going to find a gem.
The puzzles may be easy, but that isn't for lack of respect for the player. In fact, if you don't pay attention and take notes during conversations with NPCs, you're going to find yourself lost. The game points you in the right direction, but it does so while relying solely on logic. Nothing gimmicky or contrived here.
The mechanics are solid and well designed--nearly every time I ran into a wall with a puzzle, I was soon able to see that I only had myself to blame for not exploring enough or not paying enough attention during conversations. There was one puzzle that used a long-forgotten phone call as a hint that I never would have been able to solve without help, but that's the only frustration I can think of, and it was a minor one.
Unlike many adventure games, Syberia has a more realistic tone. You aren't going to find "punny" puzzles or witty flavortext. It's a calm, grounded little game with some stunning art design and sympathetic characters. If you see the value in slow-paced games and enjoy the adventure genre, give this one a shot.

For how little I bought this game for, I defnitely reccomend this game for someone who is just lookig to pass the time with a fun little game. I completed it in two days, playing for long periods of time, but including the re-do that I had to have because the game crashed on me before I saved (I hadn't saved all day so that's partially on me but.... Some pros and cons:
Pros:
For a game with 2002 graphics, the art and scenery is lovely! Also, the variety and size of locations is very pleasing, so you're not just stuck in one world that gets repetitive.
The "puzzles" are not complicated at all (this could be considered a pro if you are looking for a game that is more for passing the time and relaxation than perplexing your brain). The "puzzle" part of the game is more about finding missing objects and putting them where they go, or figuring out who you need to talk to in order to get where you want to go.
I absolutely LOVE the storyline and steampunk theme! It adds depth and creativity to the game. It is very detailed in my opinion, especially when it came to areas that acted as more of a "buffer zone" between locations of importance-- they were definitely not skipped on.
The main character is very sassy, which made me laugh a lot when she interacts with characters who are... unique.
Cons:
First thing that started bugging me was how she walks reeeeaallyy sloo
and sometimes the area you are in is on the larger side, so you can take like three sips of coffee before she even reaches the other side (I counted lol). However, overtime, I did get used to it, and eventually figured out that double clicking makes her run, which speeds up the process a bit.
Character interaction was very entertaing at times (especially when it came to Oscar), but other times I feel like certain words got a tad too repetitive within conversation, and wayy too lonngg at times.
Most of the puzzles weren't really... puzzles. Personally, they weren't hard enough for me/aren't the ones that I consider puzzles. Again, it's mostly finding things and putting stuff back together again.
Crashes. THis is a pretty old game, so it was prone to a lot of crashes if you 1) left it on too long (like for hours long btw 2) if you switch to and from different windows on your computer. However, if you save often, you should be fine.
*Extras:
Not necessarily a pro or con, but I would have really liked to have been able to control her dialogue-- not to the extent of changing the plot line, but just a tad.
Overall, I really liked this game as a time-passer. I wouldn't pay too much for it, but it was a good game, made me laugh a lot at it's colorful characters. If you want something that's relaxing, nice to look at, and non-stressful, then I would reccomend Syberia.

I beat Syberia a year or two ago and while I really enjoyed it and knew that the journey continued in Syberia II, other games and life called me away. When I learned that Syberia 3 was in the works, a fire got lit underneath me and I finally played and finished Syberia 2 in preparation. I am so glad that I didn't play Syberia 2 until 3 was announced because I think I would have some seriously unanswered questions, but lets start from the beginning.
Syberia II starts immediately after Syberia ends, so it is not so much a sequel as it is a continuation of the story. Now if you think that a game that has the story of a New York lawyer named Kate Walker going to Eastern Europe to wrap up a business deal and ends up instead helping an old man who is a genius with building automatons (NOT robots) go to the supposedly fictional island of Syberia where mammoths still live is boring, then move along. If however you think that that plot has possiblities you have to play it. I dare say it will be unlike any game you play. I know it stands out for me.
Where to even begin? I love the world that Benoit Sokal has created. Even though it is mostly snow, and blizzards and vey remote locations on the fringe of civilization, it is gorgeous. The cut scenes are exciting, beautiful, and add to the overall mystic feel of the game. The soundtrack is a wonderful blend of regular orchestral music or a tribal feel, depending on where you are in the game.
I love the characters. Seriously, if I were to pick a favorite heroine, it would be a tie between Commander Shephard and Kate Walker. I think Kate is that amazing. She doesn't save the world, but she questions the importance of having the ideal job in an ideal place. In her case it's a promising career in New York City. She learns how important it is to follow your dreams, and help others realize theirs, despite how crazy or off the beaten path they are. It's a real life lesson, and I think that is what makes her so special. The cast of characters that surround her are also memorable. I love Oscar. He may come off as annoying to some but personally I would love to go on a train adventure with him. The story really focuses on Hans, whom Kate is helping reach Syberia. It is his dream that is the focus and what drives Kate. The dynamic between these three makes this game special, and at times heartbreaking.
Of course, you can't have an adventure game without the puzzles. The key is to talk to everyone about everything you can. This will give you clues about where to go. Each area feels like a kind of level, so there are only so much backtracking. The puzzles are everywhere from pretty easy, to definitely having to think. It will just depend of your experience with adventure games.
Now I must address one thing - the ending. They got it right, mostly. Once the journey is over, there is definitely a loose string - Well, what now Kate Walker? Luckily, we will be getting the answer in Syberia 3, and I can't wait to see what new adventure she finds herself in.

The game is once again filled with superb voice acting and an excellent musical score. If you enjoyed the original game you will have a blast to continue the story which is filled with surprises and is composed together very well; the game does a good job giving the player a feeling that they are fully absorbed into this world and are connected to the characters. The length of the sequel is around the same as the original which is around 8 hours. The game also once again shines with logical and well designed puzzles which makes this game an absolute joy to play.

Syberia is one of the most emotional games I've ever played, which is quite a feat considering there aren't that many principal characters and many of them are emotionless robots. There are deeply cutting, overarching themes running through the experience that are timeless: destroyed beauty, flawed ideologies, infidelity, Peter Pan Syndrome, the inevitable march forward of technological progress and the loss of humanity. How Syberia manages to tackle such dark and depressing issues yet remain whimsical and keep you full of wonder is the mark of truly masterful writing and game design.
 
  In a modern context, a video game about economic progress and relationship troubles should rightly illicit some skepticism and groans, as “mature games” have devolved into a sort of subgenre that usually treats it's audience like complete ♥♥♥♥ing morons with no ability to parse subtext and nuance. You could go down a checklist of cliches that would (and should) instantly turn you off: “the environment is a character”, “the protagonist really grows on her journey”, etc. Here they don't feel like buzzwords, however. Syberia is art and storytelling, minus the pretension and virtue signaling.
 
  You play the game as Kate Walker, a lawyer from New York on a seemingly simple mission to get a signature from the last living heir to an obsolete toy factory. Arriving in what initially looks like a quaint European town, things quickly get very strange and her job gets exponentially more complicated. Not only has the heir died, but in her will she confesses that her brother is still alive, her family had faked his death, and his whereabouts are unknown. Kate goes above and beyond the call of duty, launching a one-woman investigation to find the mysterious genius/retard Karl Vorslberg. It's not a simple task, as Karl spent nearly his entire life designing intricate clockwork trinkets and automatons, up to and including a train to take himself to the fabled land of Syberia to look for the last living mammoths.
 
  Kate boards the train, following the clues she's found and traveling from station to station, each stop more surreal and absurd than the next. All of the locations are past their prime, crumbling monuments ravaged by time and forgotten by modern society. The inhabitants she encounters haven't fared much better; lost souls either reveling in their past glory, going through the motions like automatons themselves, or driven mad from isolation and false promises. Kate interviews them, hoping to uncover more information about Karl and the impact he had on each locale. She also grows increasingly distant from the “real” world the further down the track she goes. Faced with majestic sights, essentially becoming the biographer of a genius who would not and could not let go of childlike wonder, her mundane, adult life fades into the background. Incoming calls from her friends, family, lover, and work become either uninteresting or tools to help her on her mission of discovery.
 
  Gameplay consists of fairly standard adventure game interactions; you use the cursor to control Kate's movements, pointing and clicking to guide her. The circular reticle will light up when it's possible to move to another pre-rendered scene, or change icons if other actions are available. Talking to NPCs brings up a dialogue notebook with discussion choices, which will fill out as you obtain more information. All the voice acting is top notch, with a wide variety of accents and personality types. Kate especially is wonderful. You'll pick up items, add them to your inventory, and use them on objects... as is expected from the genre. This really is the sweet spot for adventure games as far as I'm concerned: there is some pixel hunting, but the fidelity is high enough that it's not in the literal sense. Solutions to puzzles are usually common sense, or the game actually wants you to tinker around with complex-looking machinery as part of the experience. There's nothing here that should stump you for days or have you running for a walkthrough; thorough exploration and observation is key, and it's still satisfying to solve the mechanical trials.
 
  While graphically Syberia is starting to show it's age, the sense of awe and beauty still shines through in most cases. The 3-D character models look a little rough, but thankfully the point-and-click navigation saves us from having to deal with godawful tank controls of the era. The 2-D backgrounds are pixelated but gorgeous. Oftentimes you may wonder why certain screens exist, since there are no real gameplay reason for them to be there; just “empty space”. They're there because they're pretty.
 
  Syberia is one of those games that's not technically “perfect”; you could nitpick some pacing problems or a puzzle or two that doesn't pay off, or some dialogue that's awkward or a bit too on the nose, but as a package it's absolutely fantastic. The unique, heartfelt story is something everyone should experience, and it's an adventure game you should play even if you generally don't care for adventure games. It welled me up with emotions, and I'm usually an old, crusty automaton.
Old school point-and-click. What more do you want?

As with every adventure game, a couple of puzzles are tough to crack and might take some pixel hunting to figure out but, thankfully, the number of time this happens is negligible (there's no rubber ducky puzzle).

Syberia is a really fantastic, classic point-and-click adventure game with an incredible soundtrack. You play as Miss Kate Walker, NY lawyer extraordinaire and slightly prissy investigator compelled to adventure across Europe and the Urals in search of the elusive heir to the Voralberg manufacturing plant. Initially, Kate's interest is as shallow as the sales contract she's been hired to conclude, but your adventure doesn't let that state of affairs last. In a series of beautifully imagined cities, the mystery of the Voralberg automatons, the shadowy Siberian Youkol tribe, mammoths, cold war engineering, and personal drama unfolds in puzzle after puzzle. Each challenge is integral to the world and the story, transforming Kate's character and making it difficult to tear yourself away.
In terms of gameplay, this is classic point and click from the early aughts, and is a fairly clean and easily navigable interface, though it takes a moment to get used to the dialogue setup, which is listed by general topic rather than your opening line. The graphics are great for the time and more than sufficient to show both the details of the puzzles and the creators' love for the environments. The puzzles themselves are straightforward, but may require a little creativity; several objects and areas are only accessible once Kate has spoken with another character to acquire a motive or a key.  The soundtrack is excellent and the English dub voice actors are quite good, so it remains enjoyable throughout and has good replay value. Go ahead and get the sequel, Syberia II, while you're at it, because I guarantee you'll want to keep playing when the credits roll!

Well. After having this in my library for something like 4 years, I FINALLY played it through. I started last fall, then took a hiatus in Jan., then finished it up over the last week. I had bought it as part of the Meridian pack, and there are STILL a lot in there I've never touched--yet. Anyway. I understand this game is somewhat controversial in the favorability department. I hand it a thumbs up, albeit a less than enthusiastic thumb.
First, I found the artwork and character design very good, if not actually outstanding. The steampunk vibe is excellent, and reminds me of Sierra's old masterpiece "Lighthouse: The Dark Being", considered by many to be the most insanely difficult adventure game ever made, and certainly among the best. In fact, at one point, my wife, who doesn't even play this type of game, looked over my shoulder and asked if that's what it was! Said it sounded a lot like it. Another aspect I found pleasing and familiar is that heroine Kate Walker bears a resemblance to Alex Vance, heroine of Half Life 2 and its sequels, probably my favorite game series of all time. And while this is a very different style of game, Kate also has that same tough-as-nails determination and willingness to get her hands dirty. In one sequence, she escapes a ruined underground complex through a ventilation duct -- shades of Dr Freeman himself! In fairness to Microids, let it be noted that Syberia was released more than 2 years BEFORE Alyx was helping Freeman shoot zombies.
I found most of the puzzles to be of satisfying difficulty, right in the Goldilocks zone, not too hard, not too easy, but just right. I believe I only had to go the hints (UHS reader, a valuable classic!) twice, and BOTH involved using the telephone -- I don't think it's a spoiler to say that at least twice you must make phone calls to get necessary clues -- and the first time (if I recall correctly) invokes an absolutely ABSURD coincidence! The other game it reminded me of irresistably was Douglas Adams' "Starship Titanic", with its menagerie of eccentric automatons, and one puzzle involving a mechanical bartending machine with an organ-like keyboard on which buttons are pressed and keys played seemed as if it could have been right from that ill-fated spaceship. One very clever and beautiful gimmick is a sort of music box which when wound up performs a bit of backstory from the childhood of two of the central characters, which sequences segue between the music box display itself and flashbacks to "real life".
Gameplay itself is episodic, and you progress from one city to another on a full-size wind-up train with your mechanical engineer/conductor, Oscar, solving each segment of the game. Oscar generally proves of little help to you, as wherever you stop he is afraid to leave the train because of the windy/dusty/sooty/sandy climate outside. Your quest, as Kate Walker, is tracking down a certain Hans Voralberg, creator of all these wondrous automatons and machines, to obtain his signature on a contract. Spoiler -- you succeed. This climactic moment plays out in paradoxically anti-climactic fashion -- a moment, and it's done. Then -- ah, but then you get the REAL conclusion to the saga. While not especially surprising, there is a dramatic suddenness to it and a tension which grips the player -- although at this point we have stopped really playing and are watching a cutscene play out the game's last moments.
One small issue is sequentiality. A number of times I performed some task only to find, after, characters giving me clues or Kate herself saying something which made it seem that said task still needed to be done -- or conversely, making reference to something I did NOT know yet but in a way which indicated I already had discovered some fact. Another, perhaps larger issue, is that the characters here TALK and TALK and TALK. I understand that this is something of a characteristic of European games of this type. And the accents don't help. I've also seen complaints that it is TOO episodic, and there is little sense of continuity from the beginning to the end, and sequence to sequence. Although I understand the point, I largely disagree, or disagree, at least, that it is a negative: it's just how the game plays, and is no more episodic than Myst or any of the other classic graphic adventure games. However, I must concede that it lacks SOMETHING -- but I'm not sure what. The art and music are good -- the music in fact is outstanding at times, and a musical performance is one of the key events. Some of the cinematic sequences are close to breath-taking -- I'm thinking in particular of the launch of a rocket and the flight of an airship. But the whole thing is lacking a certain spark, that special magic that takes you out of yourself and into the game itself, makes you believe that you really are immersed in a different world. It doesn't ruin the game, not by far, don't misunderstand me -- but it keeps it out of that highest level of entertainment, achieving that true suspension of disbelief. Except -- except perhaps in that final cutscene. That's where it comes closest. And I think too that a lot of players in a way ignored that conclusion, and failed to realize that the heart of the story isn't about Kate finding an old man and getting his signature, the heart of the story is KATE HERSELF. Understand this, understand the final scenes, and I think you'll appreciate this a bit more. In any case, I am now eagerly awaiting Syberia 2 to finish downloading (also part of the Meridian Collection) and look forward to playing it as well. It is coincidence that I've just found that S3 has just been released, and the first reviews and comments I've seen are rather harsh, at least with regard to the English translation and voice-acting. At $40 I'll probably wait a while until it's a Steam Special -- but play it I will!
So bottom line here -- I DO recommend this -- somewhat tentatively, perhaps -- be prepared for a thoughtful, slow-paced ride with Kate, Oscar, and their friends & enemies. It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but will be a rewarding and refreshing cup for some.

I'm a big adventure game fanatic, so I'm picky.  This one is pretty good and I think it's a great one to start out with if you're new to adventure games, because it has a good story and the problems are typically at a beginner level, without being absurdly easy.
One thing I particularly liked about the game is that it shows you very clearly what you can click on.  This is something that a lot of games lack.  I want to pull my hair out when I've been thinking and thinking about how to solve a problem in an adventure game and it turns out there was something I just didn't know I could click on (like a one-pixel wide item or something).  WIth Syberia, that's never an issue and it means that they can't rely on poorly thought-out solutions based on flailing around with the mouse to see what you can click on.
My only complaint is that there were a couple of places in which the solutions to problems were, in my opinion, not terribly intelligent.  I'm perfectly willing to take my hat off to a really clever problem that I didn't get, but it drives me nuts when these games have solutions that aren't at all clever, just non-sensical.  I'll try for hours only to give up, find an online walkthrough and then tear my hair out that the solution doesn't even make sense.  I'd advise that you don't spend too, too long on a problem you're stumped with.  Don't be ashamed to find online walkthroughs, because occasionally it's just that the problem was poorly designed.  Fortunately, those sorts of things are few and far between.
The plot is fairly original, centering around a scientist who made ingenious automata that do all sorts of amazing things and who was obsessed with the idea that wooly mammoths never died out, but still exist in some isolated part of the arctic.  My only complaint with the plot is that Syberia refers to a legendary place, not to Siberia, even though it could easily be somewhere around there.  Nobody once mentions that Syberia and Siberia are different (in fact, I don't think anyone even mentions Siberia at all) and yet, even when they're speaking orally, everyone seems to just get that Syberia means the legendary place, even though it's pronounced exactly the same. That little bit kind of rubbed me the wrong way, but, otherwise, it's quite well done and very creative.
One thing I particularly like is that you have a cell phone and you can make calls any time you want, though only to preexisting contacts, which you can add to as the game progresses.  I thought that was a nice touch.  You also get calls sometimes from people like your boss, who wants updates, and your mother and boyfriend who are both worried about you and want you to come home.
All in all, a good game.  I'd recommend it.

Disclaimer:  I'm completely shocked by 1. the copious positive reviews for this game, and 2. that the game was made in this century.  I love a good adventure game, but I'm struggling to find any lately, hence going back to some old ones and this was recommended in one of those lists, thank god I bought it on sale is all I can say at this point.   Also, it's circa 2005 with no autosave feature, I'm pretty sure other games had this by that point, what a wierd thing to not include?  Anyhow, here goes.

It's really wierd for me to bring this up as it's not really been an issue since the 80's - I've been gaming since I was 7 which was in 1988, and although some games may have some superficial problems with sexism (GTO being the worst offender, and not superfical about it either), most games by this point are far, FAR more inclusive than they were back then.  My biggest gripe with this as a female gamer is that the femminist revolution seems to be something that happened somewhere else - if the writting here is anything to go by at least.  As most of us are aware this occurred in the 60's, yet the protaganist has this strange twee way of speaking, more akin to the 19th or early 20th century.  Then there's what she's saying;  and we are supposed to believe that this woman is a lawyer?!  She spends the entire game being submissive, impassive and the entire point of her existence seems to be for her boyfriend or boss; both of whom are petulant children who need to be told to ♥♥♥♥ off, like now.  How the hell did this gal get through law school?  The side plot revolving around this is hilariously predictable and the culmination is as dull as its content.  It gets worse, the women in her life can't even get the game passed the Bechdel test (yes they only talk about Kate's boyfriend and boss) - it strikes me as stereotypical female drama (think rom-coms, I ♥♥♥♥ing hate rom-coms) as seen through the eyes of a man, a man most likely born in the 40's - it's somewhere between complete ignorance and straight up contempt.  And I don't know whether this is more confusing for me or the guy that wrote this, it's just frigging wierd.  Even by the time our protagist shrugs off the shackles that is her peer group (spoiler not spoiler - its at the end), you'll stil want to smack her in the face.  Grow a pair of ovaries love, seriously, you're embaressing the rest of us.  Then there's her personality - she's all over the place, and it doesn't really represent the unimaginative arc she's given;  Which I think is, a woman finds herself by being thrown in to a wierd adventure and in doing so realises that she can't keep sacrificing herself for what others expect and demand of her, and finally - but not really - she tells them all to do one.
What about the mechanics?  Aaaaarrrrrghhhhh!  Kate will run if you double click, this is one of the few elements this game has incorportated from more modern adventure games.  However there is no screen wrapping and every time you hit some stairs (and yes they are all over the place), kate stops suddenly as if she's come to a precipice, she then painstakingly prepares herself like an elderly person due for a hip raplcement at the bottom of said stairs, before  ardously climbing them: I'm pretty sure people pass kidney stones quicker than this.  Then there's the inventory system which is clumbsy and no you cannot combine items.  And there's the bugs, I had two crashes for no reason, and if you alt tab to say your media player on your second monitor, the background graphics get knocked out until you change scenary and trust me; you will want to watch something whilst playing this, in order to quench the sheer monotonous boredom.   You will also have to restrict the game to 256 colour in the game.exe properties in order to get it to run on win X (and most likely any OS later than XP).  Finally, beware of the huge amount of content in the form of diaries etc, as it's all as excruciatingly dull and verbose as the verbal conversations and adds very little to the story or as clues for puzzles.
Puzzles?  I can barely remember them as they are completely overshadowed by the extremely slow pacing, there were some good ones in there (I think), but the spread out environments really hurt them and are clearly another exercise in dragging the game time out.  Then there's the multitiude of unskippable animations to conversations or interactions with certain objects, it passes bordering on the ridiculous after about an hour of gameplay.  Of those puzzle's I can remember some are very poorly implemented.  For example, there's one involving a blood sample that I had to read a walkthrough for as the game gives you only one way obtaining the second sample and if you miss it and do what most people would do, you will not be able to fix it and proceed - I ended up going back a save and found that the missed option is only noticiable when you are looking for it and does not in anyway resemble the way the first sample is obtained.  This is not an isolated example and it amounts to some lazy writting and design imo.
Other problems:  The reading, oh my god the reading, there's so much and its written so, so, so badly.  The only time where the dialogue seemed less twee was in a diary, but that's only because it starts in the early 20th century!  The voice acting is nativity play calibre, and that comparison might actually be more insulting to the children.  To make matters worse these uninspired conversations go on for what seems like longer than the aforementioned diary, and they are all frigging terrible. The rest of the TWD are great and ignore the horror porn comments about the female protaganist in the second season and frontier, cos guess what? I really fell in love with this game. I first played it many, many years ago and, since then, have replayed it several times since. Each time I replay reminds me of why I fell in love in the first place.
It is the story that took me. It seem strange at first because the graphics isn't that good, the voice acting isn't the best, and the dialogue can be downright awful at times. You'd think all these factors would make the story difficult to get into...and it certainly doesn't help, that's for sure. However, I suppose what I love is the premise, the imagery, the location, and how it is all executed together.
Often, while playing through this game, I get a sense of surrealism. At times, I get drawn into the quaint loveliness of the architecture and people of Valadilene/Barrockstadt then the stark barrenness of Komkolzgrad/Aralbad, and, in the midst of this, the inexplicable impossible spring-operated automatons would be present. It's a weird mixture, but it somehow drew me in. I would feel as if I'm actually in a fantasy world exploring it.
Kind of a strange thing to feel considering that's pretty much what many games essentially is and aims to make players feel. Problem is that it seems to be so rarely achieved. In fact, of the hundreds of games I've played over the course of my life, Syberia is among a handful that actually manages to achieve it.
For that reason alone, I became a huge fan and the game gets my highest recommendation possible.

People seem to love this game and I can partly see why. As a widely recommended title of my favourite genre, it's full of original ideas, beautiful artwork and the opening scene made me feel like I was in for a real treat. The music's nice too. Looking through the Steam reviews you're hard pushed to find a bad one. Unfortunately, as much as I kept trying to love this game, it really didn't work for me.
Sadly, my defining memory of this game won't be the ever-increasing innovation of Hans Voralberg's automatons or the sheer time and effort spent on complimenting the plot via newspaper clippings, diary entries and so on. Instead, I'll remember the tedious and seemingly endless running back and forth involved EVERY STEP OF THE WAY. And I should point out that I mean the word 'step' quite literally.
I'm not sure exactly what happened to Kate Walker in the days or weeks preceding the game that makes climbing stairs such a challenge for her but as she slowly and deliberately positions herself at the bottom of even the smallest flight, before beginning her tortuous ascent, you can't help but try and solve the only truly baffling puzzle of the whole adventure - If a woman walking up some stairs is so disruptive to the game's engine then WHY PUT STAIRS IN EVERY FRAME?!
Solving a puzzle invariably involves walking back and forth through a bunch of frames multiple times in what felt to me like a shameless attempt to make the game feel as though it contains more gameplay than it really does. Don't get me wrong, I've played many point and click games in my time and know that running back and forth between frames to solve puzzles is a characteristic almost all share, but usually this is a case of necessity rather than choice and developers usually try to make it as painless as possible. In Syberia, the designers seem to have brainstormed on the question 'How can we make this game seem longer than it is?' and come up with only one solution; 'Drag every puzzle out as long as is humanly possible until finding the solution is more of a relief than a reward'.
My primary frustrations with this game are as follows:
- In some scenes you can double-click to make Kate run. In others, for some unknown reason, you can't. This gets quite annoying.
- Unneccesary and, more importantly, unskippable animations precede interactions with NPC's, which makes returning to someone you've already spoken to for a quick recap a painfully slow process. The same goes for interacting with objects.
- It's impossible to skip to the next frame with a double-click, a simple feature which would have multiplied my enjoyment of the game ten-fold.
- It takes a long time for NPC's to say anything that might be of value in some of the most wooden dialogue I've ever witnessed in a point and click game.
In short, it takes AGES to do ANYTHING. A simple puzzle that requires little thought and would be solved in seconds in better designed games (ANY Lucasarts title for example) ends up taking minutes to complete which really adds up over the course of the adventure.
This review may seem harsh but I feel that the reviews on Steam are so unfairly one-sided that a counteracting review is necessary to warn people that the slow, tedious gameplay mentioned in some of the other reviews as a potential downfall really IS enough to ruin the entire experience.
Sorry, Syberia. There were so many times when you were so close to being a great, original game but you screwed up at every opportunity by disregarding the one thing that all great games have in common: The continued engagement of the player.
If you consider yourself to be a particularly patient person who doesn't mind spending a five minutes running for every minor hunch that you have then buy this game and enjoy the good things about it. As for me, despite having bought both Syberia 1 & 2 together, I won't be playing the second one until I've finished watching all of my paint dry. At least I can do that without using any stairs.

One of the best, and most unique adventure games. It's a truly memorable classic which helped revive the genre at the time. I remember when I first learned about Syberia, the idea of a plot involving automatons and mammoths didn't excite me, but I was very curious how it all tied together. This is a slow-moving, story-heavy game with strong atmosphere and a beautiful, haunting soundtrack, as lawyer Kate Walker heads east through Europe to find an eccentric inventor. and close a business deal. In many ways this game is about Kate's character development, and you can't help but to go through the experience with her. The game seems to take place around the time it was created (2002) but as you visit the locations, touched with elements of art nouveau, steampunk, and the scars of world war, the game feels enchanting, surreal, and totally out of time in the most endearing way. The intelligent script, mysterious and charming, has it's moments of suspense and humor, too.
Now, the puzzles to be found are somewhat straight forward and will likely give you no trouble. So this isn't a puzzle-centric adventure, which may push some people away. Also, the game has been criticized for having many screens where there's nothing to interact with as you move between points of interest. I can understand that running through 4 screens of landscape at a time with nothing to do, and then running back through them, can be irritating to some people. However, I find this is something that contributes to the immersive and thoughtful tone of the game, like looking at paintings.
I should mention that while this is the must-play gem of the series, the shorter sequel is still very good, and the 3rd game, developed 13 years later and coming out next month, will no doubt be interesting.

Puzzles are all simple and very logical (which could be minus for some players). The main problem for the game in the light of todays standards is A LOT of empty and slow walking. Overall playing this game is like reading a nice art book - it will suck you in and amaze you with its ideas if you give it some time.

Like the first game, Syberia II uses its slow pace and dreamlike atmosphere to immerse the player in its wonderful world of clockwork machinery and snowy landscapes. As an adventure game, it also turned up the puzzle difficulty, sometimes significantly.
Syberia II is, from beginning to end, one large journey, continuing straight from the ending scene of the previous game. Once again, we participate in a long trip of the returning protagonist, Kate Walker and the mysterious heir she chased all the way through the first game, Hans Voralberg.
Syberia II is a sentimental tale, where the theme of the first game has matured into such questions as how long would someone go to fulfil their old dreams before their days run out, and how one can re-evaluate their purpose in life when they find a cause worthy enough to leave everything behind.
As with most stories full of allegories, it is very slow and very dreamlike. The scenery reflects how our protagonists gradually leave the edge of civilisation as the last post of humanity, a small post-Soviet barter town fades into the distance of the vast Russian tundra, where the end of the tracks may hold the answer in their search of the last resting place of the remaining mammoths, the mythical island called Syberia.
The game uses another tool to let the players immerse themselves in its world and atmosphere besides the slow pacing: the puzzles. They don’t use the warped point ‘n’ click logic that ruined many great games, but many of them rely on trial and error or constantly travelling from one end of a large gameplay area to another. The last third of the plot is especially notorious, where the difficulty quickly rises to almost legendary levels.
But all that hardship will be worth it. Worth it for one of the most bittersweet, wonderful endings we can witness in an adventure game.
